positive.review: Planet Coaster is everything I could want in a simulation game of this type. Good management tools, good building tools, and most of all, it is extremely fun to play. It's the best amusement park simulation we've seen yet, and any complaints that you might have with the variety of rides that it offers are mitigated brilliantly by the use of Steam Workshop to allow the community to broaden the experience. In this way Planet Coaster feels both nostalgic and yet eminently modern.

It took me a little while to get used to the controls, but once I did, Planet Coaster completely won me over. As someone who loved the original Roller Coaster Tycoon, this game goes far beyond what I expected. The graphics are stunning, and even with just the base game you get an impressive amount of detail, customization, and creative freedom. It truly feels like you’re managing a living, breathing theme park, from designing coasters to watching guests react to every decision you make. If you enjoy park builders or creative sandbox games, this is absolutely worth playing.

This game is tedious and unintuitive to the extreme. The grid and snapping system to try laying out paths and buildings in an orderly fashion is janky. One second i could lay down a path somewhere, then it would say it was obstructed and I couldn't. The axis system in "advanced" settings to maneuver buildings into place still fails to allow certain angles to be achieved, leaving things like the park entrance I tried to neatly build instead at a slightly off-kilter angle to the hole people would come out of. The annoyances in how the UI and placement systems worked steadily build up, and the very simple park layout I was attempting to build steadily proved to be impossible.  

I switched from sandbox to career modes to see if I'd find one of the pre-made scenarios and parks easier to manipulate, and that swiftly led to more frustrations. Got some concession stands placed at the Kraken park with only minor placement annoyances. Added scenery to the queue areas to improve attitudes of customers during their waits. Tossed down a few flat rides in empty spaces to give people more options for entertainment, and even got some scenery triggers added in to the cycles to make them more appealing. But people still wanted the main rollercoaster the most and the lines were getting massive and turning people away very quickly. So then I found myself running into an issue where an attempt to adjust the primary rollercoaster's operations, just adding an extra car to accommodate more patrons and tweaking the timings to keep the cycles along the track running smoothly, led to needing to run a safety test... A test that never ended. Just kept running without giving results. Stopped and started it a couple times, as some forum posts suggested, but the ride refused to finish the test. Removed the car, putting the ride back to its default, and ran the test again to try getting it back up and running at least to its former capacity because it was my major money maker and the park was steadily bleeding funds without it, but the test phase continued to refuse to finish. Leaving me with a dead ride taking up a bunch of space and my reputation and funds steadily dropping as customers left in a huff because they couldn't ride it.

I wasn't about to try dismantling the ride and rebuilding it from scratch, as some forum posts suggested to people for these scenarios, to see if that might get it working again. Not with as many pieces as they were and how miserable the system proved to be in Sandbox.

I turned off the game a few times and watched some videos on youtube, trying to figure out what was being done wrong, trying to find a solution that wasn't going to involve rebuilding the entire coaster- and couldn't find answers to my issues. And the game itself has zero actual tutorials to explain anything about the building or testing or financial mechanics. You're stuck wracking up time in the game while cross checking with third party sources to try figuring out what's malfunctioning. 

I passed the two hour mark for refunds, yet barely had a park running for ten minutes before it all went wrong because I tried to increase capacity to keep up with the swiftly growing line demands.

There's plenty of people who find this game fun to play, and good for them. But for me, this game was downright unintuitive and miserable to try working out anything beyond slapping down the basic blueprints already constructed and then never touching anything about them for fear of breaking one of the many unexplained mechanics. Which isn't the least bit fun to do, nor will it fulfill various demands the game will toss at you to keep patrons happy. 

This feels like such a waste of money and I really wish Steam had a slightly wider window for refunding on games.

Building anything - even plain simple paths - is just pain and terrible. You don't know what to press - and especially not press - when you build a track. Hotkeys are available but no easy accessible information available, if at all. But even with them it's just bad.
You then also have to micromanage sh*t like the staffs happiness and where to work. No, I don't want to set salaries, training, payment and working area for every one of them individually so that they just don't quit or leave the store empty.
And despite having a lot of details they still fall short on options for coasters like: No, I don't want this ride only in reverse available. Or adding a second train to this specific ride for more throughput? Nope, not here either. (It does work for some but apparently not all coasters.)
On that topic: Guests enter leave rides stupidly slow and adds additional useless "pauses" in between. Just annoying.
Want to build a stupid large park with everything and anything? Nope, not with us! 1x1 km max in size! (And no, I do not want to play tetris with this! As some suggested..)

All in all, I was annoyed by so many problems that should never have been one in the first place.
But the worst of all?
There are not mods!
Mods, like for example in Cities: Skylines (1) could fix nearly all problems with this game. But nope..
That's so frustrating and sad..

I gave this game a shot many years ago and it just didn't click. I come back year later to give  it another shot, I now know what killed it and it's the system in which you interact with the game.

My standard is Roller Coaster Tycoon. What I expected was something like City Skylines kind of interaction and complexity with the game. That is not the case.

I'm not expecting the world but I'm certainly expecting better. Sure the graphics are better but lots of things are just lacking. 
- There are themed buildings (food, restrooms, beverages, kiosk etc) where one or more themes are missing making it difficult to make a coherent themed park.
- Camera system is a struggle an a half. I'm trying to see something but then a building gets in my way obstructing the view.
- Buildings are frustrating. 
--They don't pop in at a 90 degree but at a wonky 67 degree or whatever it happens to be.
--They don't pop in level with the floor when the entire surrounding is flat.
--When I have angle activated, it's not actually an angle. Not a 47 to 50 -> 55 -> 60 -> 65, etc. No, it's a +5 in rotation 47 -> 52 ->57 -> 62, etc. This is especially infuriating when you want something flush with the sidewalk.

If you like slow build up games, detailed building options and don't mind figuring out building options and controls bit by bit by yourself while the park is constantly running and you have to deal with occuring problems on the side, then this game might be for you. 

To me personally it felt rather tedious. Snapping grids can be janky and tricky to figure out. The constant flood of notifications was a bit annoying and according to those I was only doing it right if everything in my park was free or underpriced. 

One more point which i can't hold against the game because I could have found that out prior to buying it: 
While you can build roller coasters however you like, the roller coasters measure things like Nausea and G-Forces and cannot open for visitors if those exceed certain values. So you can build freely but only use the "more harmless" ones.
Yet again, this comes with a whole testing map mechanic that shows you which parts of the ride have which problem so you can fix it which is quite neat if you are into that. I personally just expected something with a bit more freedom in terms of making my visitors empty their stomachs.

Planet Coaster game made me realise it's more the business management side of things that I enjoy than the intricate designing of rides. This game doesn't really scratch that itch. The rides that you do build require even more time theming them or everything just feels generic. If you have hours to spend designing and theming rides, then you'll probably get a lot out of it, but at a base level I didn't enjoy it.

I gave this game a shot many years ago and it just didn't click. I come back year later to give  it another shot, I now know what killed it and it's the system in which you interact with the game.

My standard is Roller Coaster Tycoon. What I expected was something like City Skylines kind of interaction and complexity with the game. That is not the case.

I'm not expecting the world but I'm certainly expecting better. Sure the graphics are better but lots of things are just lacking. 
- There are themed buildings (food, restrooms, beverages, kiosk etc) where one or more themes are missing making it difficult to make a coherent themed park.
- Camera system is a struggle an a half. I'm trying to see something but then a building gets in my way obstructing the view.
- Buildings are frustrating. 
--They don't pop in at a 90 degree but at a wonky 67 degree or whatever it happens to be.
--They don't pop in level with the floor when the entire surrounding is flat.
--When I have angle activated, it's not actually an angle. Not a 47 to 50 -> 55 -> 60 -> 65, etc. No, it's a +5 in rotation 47 -> 52 ->57 -> 62, etc. This is especially infuriating when you want something flush with the sidewalk.
Not worth your time. Refund immediately. I accidentally left it open on my computer for three years straight and I couldn't turn it off

This game is tedious and unintuitive to the extreme. The grid and snapping system to try laying out paths and buildings in an orderly fashion is janky. One second i could lay down a path somewhere, then it would say it was obstructed and I couldn't. The axis system in "advanced" settings to maneuver buildings into place still fails to allow certain angles to be achieved, leaving things like the park entrance I tried to neatly build instead at a slightly off-kilter angle to the hole people would come out of. The annoyances in how the UI and placement systems worked steadily build up, and the very simple park layout I was attempting to build steadily proved to be impossible.  

I switched from sandbox to career modes to see if I'd find one of the pre-made scenarios and parks easier to manipulate, and that swiftly led to more frustrations. Got some concession stands placed at the Kraken park with only minor placement annoyances. Added scenery to the queue areas to improve attitudes of customers during their waits. Tossed down a few flat rides in empty spaces to give people more options for entertainment, and even got some scenery triggers added in to the cycles to make them more appealing. But people still wanted the main rollercoaster the most and the lines were getting massive and turning people away very quickly. So then I found myself running into an issue where an attempt to adjust the primary rollercoaster's operations, just adding an extra car to accommodate more patrons and tweaking the timings to keep the cycles along the track running smoothly, led to needing to run a safety test... A test that never ended. Just kept running without giving results. Stopped and started it a couple times, as some forum posts suggested, but the ride refused to finish the test. Removed the car, putting the ride back to its default, and ran the test again to try getting it back up and running at least to its former capacity because it was my major money maker and the park was steadily bleeding funds without it, but the test phase continued to refuse to finish. Leaving me with a dead ride taking up a bunch of space and my reputation and funds steadily dropping as customers left in a huff because they couldn't ride it.

I wasn't about to try dismantling the ride and rebuilding it from scratch, as some forum posts suggested to people for these scenarios, to see if that might get it working again. Not with as many pieces as they were and how miserable the system proved to be in Sandbox.

I turned off the game a few times and watched some videos on youtube, trying to figure out what was being done wrong, trying to find a solution that wasn't going to involve rebuilding the entire coaster- and couldn't find answers to my issues. And the game itself has zero actual tutorials to explain anything about the building or testing or financial mechanics. You're stuck wracking up time in the game while cross checking with third party sources to try figuring out what's malfunctioning. 

I passed the two hour mark for refunds, yet barely had a park running for ten minutes before it all went wrong because I tried to increase capacity to keep up with the swiftly growing line demands.

There's plenty of people who find this game fun to play, and good for them. But for me, this game was downright unintuitive and miserable to try working out anything beyond slapping down the basic blueprints already constructed and then never touching anything about them for fear of breaking one of the many unexplained mechanics. Which isn't the least bit fun to do, nor will it fulfill various demands the game will toss at you to keep patrons happy. 

This feels like such a waste of money and I really wish Steam had a slightly wider window for refunding on games.

They put *a lot* of work into a lot of details n'stuff but yet this game falls really short on the basics: The controls are terrible, mostly unintuitive, and often not even described. Building anything - even plain simple paths - is just pain and terrible. You don't know what to press - and especially not press - when you build a track. Hotkeys are available but no easy accessible information available, if at all. But even with them it's just bad.
You then also have to micromanage sh*t like the staffs happiness and where to work. No, I don't want to set salaries, training, payment and working area for every one of them individually so that they just don't quit or leave the store empty.
And despite having a lot of details they still fall short on options for coasters like: No, I don't want this ride only in reverse available. Or adding a second train to this specific ride for more throughput? Nope, not here either. (It does work for some but apparently not all coasters.)
On that topic: Guests enter leave rides stupidly slow and adds additional useless "pauses" in between. Just annoying.
Want to build a stupid large park with everything and anything? Nope, not with us! 1x1 km max in size! (And no, I do not want to play tetris with this! As some suggested..)

All in all, I was annoyed by so many problems that should never have been one in the first place.
But the worst of all?
There are not mods!
Mods, like for example in Cities: Skylines (1) could fix nearly all problems with this game. But nope..
That's so frustrating and sad..
